newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft backs Web profiling proposal.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft backs Web profiling proposal.

text.p: Privately held Firefly Network Inc and Netscape Communications Corp said Microsoft Corp is cooperating in building on the Open Profiling Standard for the Internet they proposed two weeks ago.

The announcement, made as the U.S. Federal Trade Commission held hearings on Internet privacy, will bring added momentum to the proposal, which aims to provide a framework for built-in privacy safeguards and greater individual control over exchange of personal information over the Internet.

Firefly, Netscape, Microsoft and privately held VeriSign will work together on the new protocol during the remainder of a standards review process of the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C), which is the Web's main standards body.

"We're delighted that Microsoft, Netscape and Firefly have chosen to work together with our staff and other member organizations," Jim Miller, leader of the technology and society domain of the World Wide Web consortium, said in a statement.
In the two weeks since its unveiling, support for the standards effort has grown to include more than 100 companies, according to a statement released by a Firefly representative.
